pullRequest.body:
Adding equivalence between OnePoint K and projective line over K, as discussed at https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/.E2.9C.94.20Projective.20extended.20real.20line/near/463620378

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [3de095d989](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16128/commits/3de095d9893e46b52bc2ec47b92f681b16063daa)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Topology.Compactification.OnePointEquiv`|1214|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ divOnePoint`
`+ divOnePoint'`
`+ divOnePoint_lifts`
`+ divSlope`
`+ divSlope_equiv`
`+ divSlope_inj_lifted`
`+ divSlope_injective`
`+ divSlope_inv`
`+ divSlope_surjective`
`+ instance {K : Type} [DivisionRing K] : Setoid ({v : Fin 2 → K // v ≠ 0})`
`+ not_both_zero`
`+ slope_inv`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>
Closing this, as it had a git branching issue and was replaced by https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/16152

Thanks for your contribution and welcome to mathlib!
I left a few comments, mostly about coding style. (It is completely normal that the first rounds of PR review center on this.) Please take a look, and remove the `awaiting-author` label once you have incorporated these comments.

This should fix the warning about shake:
```suggestion

I would write something like this: "One-point compactification and projectivization"
(My understanding is that mathlib does not perform special capitalisation in module docstrings.)
I just saw that `OnePoint` does the same: that could be fixed independently.
Can you mention this result's name, please?
At this point, the reader has not seen `divOnePoint` and `divSlope` - can you tweak this explanation, please?
Normally, I would speak about `{v : Fin 2 → K} (hv : v ≠ 0)`. Any reason you are not doing this here?

The same applies to most lemmas below. I checked a few of them; my impression is that the proof can always be fixed. Can you try to adapt your lemmas and proofs - feel free to ask on zulip in case you need help fixing the proofs!

Thanks @grunweg for all the comments!
In my mind I was following the [projectivization](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/LinearAlgebra/Projectivization/Basic.html#projectivizationSetoid) definitions.
Also, compare
`(a b : {v : Fin 2 → K // v ≠ 0})`
versus
`(a b : Fin 2 → K) (ha : a ≠ 0) (hb : b ≠ 0)`.
In the first line the reader doesn't have to visually verify that the assumptions on `a` and `b` are indeed the same. It's basically the "Don't repeat yourself" (DRY) software principle.
What do you think?

(For just one variable I am fine with changing it from
`(a : {v : Fin 2 → K // v ≠ 0})`
to
`(a : Fin 2 → K) (ha : a ≠ 0)`; it seems both have their advantages.)

About the DRY thing: I understand your point; my personal preference is more towards `{a b : Fin 2 → K} (ha : a ≠ 0) (hb : b ≠ 0)`, the arguments `a` and `b` being implicit.
One detail to take into account could be how this lemma will be used: is it used with `v` or with `a` and `ha`?

OK I can go either way... In what I'm doing the lemma will be used with `v` in the sense that we are carrying around nonzero vectors, rather than carrying around vectors that may or may not be nonzero. Not sure if that answers your question.
Can you please mention this notation above, both in the module docstring and the definition of `divOnePoint`?
`div_onePoint` does not exist: did you forget to adjust the comments when renaming?

As an example: you could rewrite this lemma, using just `v : Fin 2 → K` as
```
lemma not_both_zero {K : Type} [Zero K] {v : Fin 2 → K} (hv : v ≠ 0) (h : v 1 = 0) : v 0 ≠ 0 := by
  by_contra h'
  have : v = 0 := by
    ext s
    cases (Nat.le_one_iff_eq_zero_or_eq_one.mp (Fin.is_le s)) with
    |inl h'' => rw [Fin.eq_of_val_eq (j := 0) h'']; exact h'
    |inr h'' => rw [Fin.eq_of_val_eq (j := 1) h'']; exact h
  exact hv this

A style nitpick: mathlib style puts a space after comma and semicolon, so this would be `field_simp at h'; rw [h', mul_comm]`.
(Also, semicolons are used sparingly: tactic calls *can* be put on the same line if they really logically belong together. But this should be intentional.)
This can be simplified, as `simp_all [Fin.eq_of_val_eq (j := 1) hr]` (also in a few more places above and below).
If you change `not_both_zero` as above, this `have` can be simplified to `not_both_zero a.2 g₀`

Mathlib style is this:
```suggestion
  Quotient.ind (fun a ↦ Quotient.ind (divSlope_inj_lifted a))

Mathlib style is this:
```suggestion
  Quotient.ind (fun a ↦ Quotient.ind (divSlope_inj_lifted a))
Also here, use `fun` instead of `λ `, please.
You can fix the error by making this a `noncomputable def` instead.

I like these changes, but they modify a completely different file. Can you remove them from this PR? Feel free to submit a new PR with them; if you @mention me, I will do my best to review it quickly.

Oops, these changes were part of an earlier PR that was approved. Didn't mean to include them again! Maybe what happened was that I wrote
`git switch -c bjoernkjoshanssen_measure_comap_injectivity`
back in July and I wrote
`git switch -c bjoernkjoshanssen_onepoint`
yesterday, but I should have done
`git switch -c master`
in between? I'll just make a corrected PR...

That sounds plausible; running `git switch -c branchname` creates a new branch based on the branch you currently have checked out. Switching to `master` before running this ensures your branch is based on master (which is what you want here).
(Sometimes, the other behaviour, branching your branch on top of an existing branch, is precisely what you want. It depends.)

pullRequest.title: feat: equivalence between one-point compactification and projective line
